column4: We get a message "your $HOME/.dmrc file has the wrong permissions..." when trying to boot up. We've attempted to move the /home folder to it's own partition on another drive - that failed - so we renamed the back up home_backup back to /home with the mv command and the system won't boot.  Any help would be apreciated.
where <username> is the user's name
put the original home back, and run   sudo chown <username>:<username> /home/<username>/.dmrc && chmod 600 /home/<usrname>/.dmrc
thanks  - the error message advises owned by owner and permissions 644  -  which is better
if the error says that, it's ok. Just has to be readable by your regular user. I use 600 since I use 00 as group and other read/write
thanks tons  --
would you know also if the entries in fstab need to be in any certain order ?
no, order doesn't matter
only the /root one really matters, and it get's mounted first thing by the kernel
excellent, thanks again. :)
does one use or not use the <brackets> in that command ?
no brackets, that's a convention to indicate you need to fill in the blanks
the command returns invalid user
is it 'cause we're booted from the live CD
, ah
you need to do that to the directory on the disk
so need to mount it first
yes. And probably just setting the   chmod 644 /home/username/.dmrc would be sufficient
doing a chown from the live cd won't work, since there is no such user in the live cd environment
it's the only way we can find to boot up though  -  are we behind the eight ball
hard to do serious troubleshooting 3d hand, it's hard enough second hand. Why not invite him here?
